Award.AwardTitle: Assembling the Tree of Life: Can Phylogenomics Resolve Deep Phylogeny?
Award.AbstractNarration:
Resolving the topology and relative timing of the deepest branches remains one of the most significant challenges in Assembling the Tree of Life. Knowledge of this deep phylogeny, however, is critical for understanding foundational questions in biology such as how the complex networks that underlie modern life arose, and how they have been shaped by co-evolution with the Earth. This research project will develop new algorithms to infer a Tree of Life that is based on the thousands of complete genome sequences currently available rather than a single gene or small set of genes. Accurately identifying and accounting for horizontal gene transfer, a process in which genes are exchanged between unrelated species, potentially obscuring phylogenetic relationships, is a key challenge that will be addressed. Calibrating the timing of the deepest branches on the Tree of Life with the geological record will be done in collaboration with experts in early Earth history and geochronology.

This project will result in a better understanding of the origin and history of life on Earth, and new algorithms for inferring the evolutionary history of genes and species across billions of years of evolutionary time. The project will bring together expertise from diverse fields of study, and expose graduate, undergraduate, and postdoctoral students to interdisciplinary research. In addition, museum partnerships and podcasts will enable dissemination of research results to the general public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Little is known about the first ~3 billion years of life on our planet. Yet the microorganisms that thrived during this period transformed our world, generating the oxygenated atmosphere that persists to the day, and ultimately giving rise to the complex forms of life including humans.

Part of the reason that this period is poorly understood is that microbial forms are largely invisible from the fossil record. And the microfossils that do exist tell little about the function of the organisms that left them.

This project aimed to take a different approach to studying the earliest life, looking at the DNA of existing organisms. These DNA sequences bear an imprint of billions of years of change, and by comparing the sequences of multiple species, it is possible to infer the sequence of long-extinct precursors. This project took this approach one step further, by inferring the entire genomes of ancient species, and tracking when and how different metabolisms came into existence. 

By comparing the emergence of key metabolic processes to chemical information from ancient rocks, it was possible to connect these very different sources of information on early life. This multi-disciplinary approach integrated data from biology, geology, and chemistry to make key scientific discoveries.

This project reported the first DNA evidence for the "Great Oxidation Event", a key geochemical event in Earth history during which the atmosphere of the planet went from anoxic to oxygenated. This event was most likely the largest ecological catastrophe in Earth history, since most organisms alive prior to that date were strict anaerobes unable to deal with the toxic nature of molecular oxygen.

More recently, this project resulted in another mass extinction-related discovery. The Permian-Triassic extinction is the largest mass extinction recorded in the fossil record. Little is known about its cause, although multiple theories exist. This project identified a key genetic innovation leading to faster methane gas production, and ultimately to CO2 buildup that destroyed 90% of marine species. Interestingly, this innovation followed a large volcanic eruption that added considerable amounts of Nickel to the biosphere, a trace element needed by methane-producing organisms. This influx may have primed the system for genetic innovation, highlighting the surprising connection between biotic and abiotic processes in evolution.

In addition to these important scientific discoveries, this project resulted in a number of software packages that will allow scientists around the world to replicate these results, and conduct similar studies in the future. Many of the young scientists that worked on this project have furthered their careers during the process, and now hold faculty positions at prestigious universities such as MIT, Johns Hopkins, and Duke. Finally, this project engaged the Acera school, a K-8 school dedicated to science, creativity, and leadership, by linking teams of elementary and middle school children with graduate students to develop curriculum for disseminating research findings with the general public.
